definition.text: a cartoon rabbit who likes carrots and often uses the phrase ‘What’s up, Doc?’

inflections: ( plural bunnies )
title: bunny

definition.text: a word for a rabbit, used especially by or to children

a) to ask people to pay attention to a particular subject or problem
b) to make someone notice someone or something

definition.text: the process or result of something or someone becoming different

examples.text: I find it hard to cope with change.
scientists worried about climatic change
change in
changes in the immigration laws
A change in personality may mean your teenager has a drug problem.
change of
a change of temperature
No major changes were made to the book.
change for the better/worse(= a change that makes a situation better or worse )
There was a change for the better in the patient’s condition.
social/political/economic etc change
the sweeping political changes after the fall of communism
She had a change of heart (= change in attitude ) and decided to stay.
Family life has undergone dramatic change in recent years.

definition.text: the fact of one thing or person being replaced by another

examples.text: The car needs an oil change.
change of
a change of government
a change of address
change from something to something
the gradual change from grasslands to true desert
The government has made some major policy changes .

definition.text: a situation or experience that is different from what happened before, and is usually interesting or enjoyable

examples.text: change from
The morning was cool; a welcome change from the heat of the day before.
for a change
How about dinner out for a change?
it/that makes a change(= used to say that something is better than and different from usual )
‘Ron’s buying the drinks.’ ‘That makes a change.’
change of scene/air/pace etc(= when you go to a different place or do something different )
The patients benefit greatly from a change of scenery.
a change is as good as a rest(= used to say that starting to do something different is as good as having a rest )

definition.text:
a) the money that you get back when you have paid for something with more money than it costs
b) money in the form of coins, not paper money
c) coins or paper money that you give in exchange for the same amount of money in a larger unit

meaning.translation: باقی مانده پول ، سکه ، پول خرد

examples.text: Here’s your change, sir.
in change
I have about a dollar in change.
Matt emptied the loose change from his pockets.
A beggar asked for some spare change (= coins that you do not need ) .
change for £1/$10
Excuse me, have you got change for a pound?
make change(= give someone change )
Can you make change for $20?

definition.text:
a)coins you have that do not have a high value
b)used to emphasize that something is a small amount of money when it is compared to a larger amount

examples.text: I only had about a pound in small change.
The program costs $20 million a year, small change by Washington standards.

definition.text: an additional set of clothes that you have with you, for example when you are travelling
a situation in which you get off one train, bus, or aircraft and get on another in order to continue your journey

examples.text: Even with a change of trains, the subway is quicker than a cab at rush hour.

definition.lexUnit: get no change out of somebody
definition.text: to get no useful information or help from someone

examples.text: I wouldn’t bother asking Richard – you’ll get no change out of him.

definition.text: to become different, or to make something become different

examples.text: Susan has changed a lot since I last saw her.
Changing your eating habits is the best way to lose weight.
The leaves on trees change colour in the autumn.
change (from something) to something
He changed from being a nice lad to being rude and unhelpful.
change into
The hissing sound gradually changed into a low hum.
change somebody/something into something
A witch had changed him into a mouse.
change something to something
Mueller changed his name to Miller when he became a U.S. citizen.

definition.text: to stop doing or using one thing, and start doing or using something else instead

examples.text: She changed jobs in May.
change (from something) to something
The company has recently changed to a more powerful computer system.
The ship changed course and headed south.
The company has had to change direction because of developments in technology.

definition.text: to put or use something new or different in place of something else, especially because it is old, damaged, or broken

examples.text: Three boys were changing a tyre by the side of the road.
When I lost my keys, we had to change all the locks.

The time of the meeting has been changed from 11:00 to 10:30.

definition.text: to change your decision, plan, or opinion about something

examples.text: Her father tried to get her to change her mind.

If you change your mind about the job, just give me a call.

definition.text: to leave one party, group etc and join an opposing party, group etc

examples.text: It’s quite rare for politicians to change sides.

definition.text:
a) to take off your clothes and put on different ones
b) to put a clean nappy on a baby, or to put clean clothes on a baby or small child

Sara changed into her swimsuit and ran out for a quick swim.

Can you change the baby?

definition.text: to take the dirty sheets off a bed and put on clean ones

b) to give a customer something different instead of what they have bought, especially because there is something wrong with it

examples.text: change something for something
I bought these gloves for my daughter, but they’re too large. Can I change them for a smaller size?
I’m sure the shop will change them for you.

definition.text:
a) to get smaller units of money that add up to the same value as a larger unit
b) to get money from one country for the same value of money from another country

definition.text: to get off one train, bus, or aircraft and onto another in order to continue your journey

meaning.translation: عوض کردن (قطار ، اتوبوس ، هواپیما و غیره)

change trains/buses/planes etc
I had to change planes in Denver.

meaning.translation: تغییر مالکیت دادن ، دست کسی دیگه افتادن

definition.text:
a)to give someone your place and take their place
b)to take someone else’s social position or situation in life instead of yours

definition.text: to put the engine of a vehicle into a higher or lower gear in order to go faster or slower

examples.text: US business has changed its spots in recent years.

definition.text: to quickly follow someone or something in order to catch them

the act of following someone or something quickly in order to catch them

definition.text: when you use a lot of time and effort trying to get something

examples.text: chase after
the chase after higher-paying jobs

definition.text: to bite food several times before swallowing it

examples.text: This meat’s so tough I can hardly chew it!

a dog chewing on a bone

definition.text: to bite something continuously in order to taste it or because you are nervous

We gave the dog an old shoe to chew on.
chew your lip/nails
chew gum/tobacco

to have a long friendly conversation
the act of biting something many times with your teeth
a sweet that you chew
a piece of tobacco that you chew but do not swallow

definition.text: to succeed in communicating ideas or information to other people

It’s important that we get this message over to young people.

definition.text: to do and finish something difficult that you have to do

meaning.translation: تمام کردن و به سرانجام رساندن یک کار سخت که باید انجام می شد

examples.text: I’ll be in touch once I’ve got my exams over.
I can’t wait to get the interview over with.

definition.text: to successfully deal with a problem or difficulty

examples.text: I don’t know how we’re going to get over this problem.
Once we’ve got over the first few months, we should be making a reasonable profit.

definition.text: used to say that you are very surprised, shocked, or amused by something

examples.text: I can’t get over how well you look.

definition.text: to stop being so sensitive or proud

examples.text: Get over yourself! Nobody cares if you’ve made a mistake.

definition.text: to have the opportunity to do something

examples.text: We got to meet all the stars after the show.
She gets to travel all over the place with her job.

definition.text: to leave a place, especially in order to do something

examples.text: John decided to go off on his own.
to
He went off to work as usual.
go off to do something
Geoff went off to play golf.

definition.text: to explode or fire

examples.text: The bomb went off at 6.30 this morning.
Fireworks were going off all over the city.
The gun went off and the bullet went flying over his head.

definition.text: if an alarm goes off, it makes a noise to warn you about something

examples.text: The thieves ran away when the alarm went off.
I’ve set the alarm clock to go off at 7 am.

definition.text: to stop liking something or someone

meaning.translation: علاقه خود را به کسی یا چیزی از دست دادن

examples.text: Many women go off coffee during pregnancy.
go off doing something
I’ve gone off cooking lately.

definition.text: if a machine or piece of equipment goes off, it stops working

examples.text: The central heating goes off at 9 o’clock.
Suddenly, all the lights went off.

definition.text: to happen in a particular way

examples.text: The party went off very well.

definition.text: to happen

examples.text: There was a blazing row going off next door.

definition.text: if food goes off, it becomes too bad to eat

examples.text: The milk’s gone off.

definition.text: to go to sleep

examples.text: I’d just gone off to sleep when the phone rang.

definition.text: to get worse

examples.text: He’s a singer whose talent has gone off in recent years.

definition.text:
a) a gross sum of money is the total amount before any tax or costs have been taken away
b) a gross weight is the total weight of something, including its wrapping

meaning.translation: آ) مقدار کل پول قبل از کسر مالیات یا سایر هزینه ها ب) وزن کل یک چیز با بسته بندی آن

examples.text: a gross profit of $5 million
gross income/salary/pay etc
a family with gross earnings of just £75 per week

definition.text: clearly wrong and unacceptable

examples.text: gross negligence/misconduct etc
soldiers accused of gross violations of human rights
The company described reports of environmental disaster as gross exaggeration.
gross indecency(= the crime of doing something that is sexually offensive )

definition.text: very unpleasant to look at or think about

examples.text: Ooh, gross! I hate spinach!

definition.text: extremely fat and unattractive
to gain an amount as a total profit, or earn it as a total amount, before tax has been taken away

examples.text: The movie has already grossed over $10 million.

inflections: ( plural gross )
title: gross

definition.text: a quantity of 144 things

examples.text: gross of
two gross of candles

definition.text: to earn £20,000 etc before tax has been taken away

examples.text: a junior executive earning $50,000 gross

definition.text: a group of animals of one kind that live and feed together

examples.text: herd of
a herd of cattle
herds of elephants

definition.text: people generally, especially when thought of as being easily influenced by others

examples.text: You have to be an individual; it’s no use running with the herd.
the herd instinct (= the need to behave in the same way as everyone else does )

definition.text: to bring people together in a large group, especially roughly

meaning.translation: جمع کردن افراد بویژه با رفتاری خشن

examples.text: The prisoners were herded together .
I don’t want to be herded around with a lot of tourists.

The visitors were herded into two large halls.

definition.text: to make animals move together in a group

meaning.translation: حرکت دادن حیوانات در یک گروه

examples.text: It was Tom’s duty to herd the cows.

definition.text: used to say that trying to control or organize a group of people is very difficult
to travel to places by getting free rides from drivers of passing cars

examples.text: hitchhike around/to/across etc
She spent her gap year hitchhiking around the world.

definition.text: the opinion or feeling you have about someone or something because of the way they seem

meaning.translation: برداشت یا احساسی که در مورد یک شخص یا یک چیز داریم بخاطر ظاهرشون

examples.text: When we looked around the school we got a very good impression.
I got the impression that she wasn't very happy with her job.
impression of
What was your impression of Roger?

definition.text: to believe that something is true when it is not

examples.text: I’m sorry, I was under the impression that you were the manager.

definition.text: if you do an impression of a famous person, you copy their speech or behaviour in order to make people laugh

meaning.translation: عمل ادای کسی را در آوردن

examples.text: Jean does a great impression of Madonna.

definition.text: a picture or drawing of what someone or something might look like, or what something will look like in the future

examples.text: impression of
an artist’s impression of the new building

definition.text: a mark left by pressing something into a soft surface

examples.text: Some of the fallen trees had left a clear impression in the hardened mud.

definition.text: all the copies of a book printed at one time
the finger next to your thumb
an innate quality or ability is something you are born with

examples.text: Children have an innate ability to learn language.

definition.text: an innate belief is something you feel strongly about and are unlikely to change

examples.text: the innate conservatism of the farming community

definition.text: someone who buys, sells, makes, or repairs jewellery

meaning.translation: طلا فروش ، طلا ساز ، تعمیرکار طلا

definition.text: a shop selling jewellery and watches
the belief that all the good and bad things that you do in this life affect how good or bad your future lives will be, according to the Hindu and Buddhist religions
the feeling that you get from a person, place, or action

examples.text: good/bad karma
The house had a lot of bad karma.

definition.text: your knuckles are the joints in your fingers, including the ones where your fingers join your hands

examples.text: Her knuckles whitened as she gripped the gun.

definition.text: a piece of meat around the lowest leg joint of a pig

examples.text: a knuckle of pork

definition.text: rude, or likely to give offence

examples.text: Some of his jokes are a bit near the knuckle.

definition.text: animal skin that has been treated to preserve it, and is used for making shoes, bags etc

examples.text: The inside of the bag was lined with soft leather.
elegant leather boots

definition.text: special leather clothes worn for protection by someone riding a motorcycle
in a way that is not firm or tight

examples.text: A towel was loosely wrapped around his neck.

definition.text: in a way that is not exact

examples.text: The film is loosely based on the novel.
‘El Libre’ was loosely translated as ‘the free one’.

definition.text: in a way that is not strictly controlled or organized

examples.text: a loosely structured organization

definition.text: someone’s minions are the people who just obey their orders and do unskilled work – used humorously

examples.text: I was shown into the office by one of her minions.

definition.text: a short traditional poem or song for children

meaning.translation: یک شعر کوتاه قدیمی برای کودکان

f2n.heading: Register
f2n.explanation: In everyday English, people often say that someone has nothing on or doesn’t have anything on rather than say they are naked :
examples: They ran through the yard with nothing on .

definition.text: not wearing any clothes or not covered by clothes

examples.text: The children ran naked through the yard.
a picture of a naked man
They found the body lying half naked in the grass.
The governor ordered the prisoner to be stripped naked and whipped.
stark naked buck naked/naked as a jaybird(= completely naked )

definition.text: if you can see something with the naked eye, you can see it without using any artificial help such as a telescope or microscope

examples.text: with the naked eye
It’s just about possible to see the planet with the naked eye on a clear night.
visible/invisible to the naked eye
Dust mites are tiny creatures, invisible to the naked eye.

definition.text: weak and unable to protect yourself

examples.text: Standing in front on his first day of teaching, Brad felt completely naked .

definition.text: truth, self-interest, aggression etc that is not hidden and is shocking

examples.text: The president condemned the invasion as an act of naked aggression.

definition.text: a light, flame etc that is not enclosed by a cover

examples.text: A naked light bulb dangled from the ceiling.

definition.text: used when saying what bad thing will happen if something is not done

examples.text: You’ll have to go now, otherwise you’ll miss your bus.
Put your coat on, otherwise you’ll get cold.

definition.text: used when saying what would have happened or might have happened if something else had not happened

examples.text: We were delayed at the airport. Otherwise we would have been here by lunch time.
They got two free tickets to Canada, otherwise they’d never have been able to afford to go.

definition.text: to say, think, or decide something different

examples.text: The government claims that the economy is improving, but this survey suggests otherwise.
A lot of people think otherwise.

definition.text: except for what has just been mentioned

examples.text: He was tired but otherwise in good health.
I could hear the distant noise of traffic. Otherwise all was still.
This spoiled an otherwise excellent piece of work.
Their arrival livened up an otherwise dull afternoon.

definition.text: used to refer to the opposite of what has just been mentioned

examples.text: We welcome any comments from viewers, favourable or otherwise.
The truth or otherwise of this diagnosis would be revealed in the future.

definition.text: busy doing something else

examples.text: I’m afraid I will be otherwise engaged that day.

definition.text: also called

meaning.translation: هم چنین شناخته شده به عنوان

examples.text: Albert DeSalvo, otherwise known as the Boston Strangler

definition.text: in a different way

examples.text: people who smoke or otherwise abuse their bodies

definition.lexUnit: it cannot be otherwise/how can it be otherwise?
definition.text: used to say that it is impossible for something to be different from the way it is

meaning.translation: نمی تواند غیر از این باشد / چطور می تواند غیر از این باشد؟

examples.text: Life in the military is hard – how can it be otherwise?

definition.text: a hard salty type of bread baked in the shape of a stick or a loose knot
to make the sound of a letter, word etc, especially in the correct way

examples.text: How do you pronounce your name?

definition.text: to officially state that something is true

examples.text: pronounce somebody/something sth
The victim was pronounced dead on arrival.
I now pronounce you man and wife.

definition.text: to give a judgment or opinion

examples.text: The scheme was pronounced a failure.
pronounce on/upon
He used to pronounce on matters he knew nothing about.

definition.text: to give a legal judgment

examples.text: pronounce sentence(= tell a court of law what punishment a criminal will have )

definition.text: to breathe quickly and with difficulty after the effort of running, carrying something heavy etc

examples.text: George puffed and panted as he tried to keep up.
puff along/up etc
An old man puffed up to them.
He caught up with Gary, puffing for breath .

definition.text: to breathe in and out while smoking a cigarette or pipe

meaning.translation: دود کردن سیگار ، پیپ و غیره

examples.text: puff at/on
Kinane sat in silence, puffing thoughtfully at his pipe.

definition.text: if smoke, steam etc puffs from somewhere, or if something puffs it, it comes out in little clouds

examples.text: Steam puffed out of the chimney.
The boiler was puffing thick black smoke.
Don’t puff smoke into my face.

definition.text: to move in a particular direction, sending out little clouds of steam or smoke

examples.text: The train puffed steadily across the bridge.

definition.text: the action of taking the smoke from a cigarette, pipe etc into your lungs

examples.text: puff on/at
He laughed and took a puff on his cigar.

definition.text: a sudden small movement of wind, air, or smoke

examples.text: puff of smoke/wind/air/steam etc
The dragon disappeared in a puff of smoke.

definition.text: a piece of light pastry with a soft mixture inside
your breath

examples.text: I was out of puff (= had difficulty breathing ) .

definition.text: a piece of writing or a speech that praises someone too much – used to show disapproval
to make a fire etc stop burning

examples.text: The rescue services are still trying to put out the fires.

definition.text: to make a light stop working by pressing or turning a button or switch
to put things where people can find and use them

examples.text: The girls helped her to put out the cups and plates.

definition.text: to feel upset or offended

examples.text: We were a little put out at not being invited to the wedding.

definition.text: to make extra work or cause problems for someone

examples.text: Mary can’t come to dinner tonight. She hopes it won’t put you out.

definition.text: to make an effort to do something that will help someone

examples.text: They had put themselves out to entertain her during her visit.

definition.text: to take something outside your house and leave it there

examples.text: Remember to put the cat out before you go to bed.
put the rubbish/garbage etc out(= put unwanted things outside your house to be taken away )
put the washing out(= put clothes outside to dry )

definition.text: to push your tongue out of your mouth, especially as a rude sign to someone
to move your hand etc forward and away from your body

examples.text: He put out his hand toward her.

definition.text: to make someone unconscious before a medical operation
to injure your back
to broadcast or produce something for people to read or listen to

examples.text: They put out a half-hour programme on young refugees.

definition.text: to try to discover information or opinions by listening to people or watching what is happening

examples.text: He had already put out feelers with local employers but they hadn’t been interested.

definition.text: if a ship puts out, it starts to sail
if a woman puts out, she has sex with a man
to prevent a baseball player from running around the bases, for example by catching the ball that they have hit
upset or offended

examples.text: She felt put out that she hadn’t been consulted.

definition.text: to choose someone or something from a group

examples.text: She picked out a navy blue dress.
His story was picked out as the best by the judges.

definition.text: to recognize someone or something in a group of people or things

examples.text: She was able to pick out her father at the other side of the room.
I picked out Valerie’s voice from among the general conversation.

definition.text: if you can pick something out, you can see it but not very clearly

examples.text: I could just pick out some letters carved into the stone.

definition.text: if something is picked out, it is in a different colour or material from the background, so that it can be clearly seen

examples.text: His name was picked out in gold lettering.

definition.text: to play a tune on a musical instrument slowly or with difficulty

examples.text: He sat at the piano and picked out a simple tune.

definition.text:
a) to give drugs to a sick animal so that it dies without too much pain – used to avoid saying the word ‘ kill ’
b) to make someone unconscious before a medical operation by giving them drugs

meaning.translation: آ) خلاص کردن (کشتن) یک حیوان بیمار ب) بیهوش کردن یک شخص قبل از عمل جراحی

inflections: ( past tense and past participle put, present participle putting )
title: put_verb_1

definition.text: to move something to a particular place or position, especially using your hands

examples.text: He put the coffee on the table.

inflections: ( past tense and past participle put, present participle putting )
title: put_verb_2

definition.text: to make someone be in a situation or have a feeling

examples.text: Don’t put yourself into a situation you can’t handle.
put somebody in a good/bad etc mood(= make them feel happy/annoyed etc )
The long delay had put us all in a bad mood.
I don’t want to put you in danger .
Pit closures have put thousands of miners out of a job (= made them lose their job ) .
put somebody in control/command/charge etc(= give someone authority over a group, activity, or organization )
His boss resigned and Murphy was put in charge.
Politics puts me to sleep .
A knee injury put him out of action for three months.

inflections: ( past tense and past participle put, present participle putting )

meaning.translation: نوشتن یا چاپ کردن چیزی یا علامت زدن با خودکار یا مداد

examples.text: put something in/on/under etc something
Put your name at the top of each answer sheet.
put something to something(= he signed it to show he agreed with it )
He put his signature to the contract (= he signed it to show he agreed with it ) .

inflections: ( past tense and past participle put, present participle putting )
title: put_verb_4

meaning.translation: بیان کردن یا نوشتن چیزی با استفاده از کلمات به نحوی خاص

examples.text: put something well/cleverly/simply etc
The question was well put.
So it was an accident, an ‘act of God’ if you want to put it like that .
When women joined the organization, it ‘took on a new look', as news reports put it .
It is hard to put into words (= express ) how I feel now.
He’s not very musical, to put it mildly (= he’s not musical at all ) .
We get on each other’s nerves, to put it bluntly (= to say exactly what I mean ) .
It’s fairly risky. Or to put it another way (= say it in different words ), don’t try this at home.
The subject matter makes the painting a little, how shall I put it (= how can I say it politely? ), undesirable for public display.

inflections: ( past tense and past participle put, present participle putting )

meaning.translation: متوقف کرد یک فعالیت مضر یا غیرقابل قبول

examples.text: We must put an end to their threats.

meaning.translation: بکار گرفتن یک طرح ، ایده ، دانش و غیره

examples.text: put somebody in (something)

definition.lexUnit: put somebody on a train/plane etc

definition.text: used to say that you would not be surprised if someone did something bad or unusual because it is typical of them to do that type of thing

examples.text: $500? OK, it’s a deal. Put it there!

relieve the boredom/monotony

examples.text: a rough sketch of the house

examples.text: The project was finally given the thumbs up .
Her performance got the thumbs down from the critics.

definition.text: to be so strongly influenced by someone that they control you completely

examples.text: He was still under his father’s thumb.

definition.text: to persuade a driver of a passing car to stop and take you somewhere, by putting your hand out with your thumb raised

examples.text: I thumbed a lift into town.

definition.text: to show that you do not respect rules, laws etc or you do not care what someone thinks of you

examples.text: a chance to thumb his nose at the college authorities

definition.text: a soft silver-white metal that is often used to cover and protect iron and steel . It is a chemical element : symbol Sn

examples.text: an old tin bath

definition.text: thin shiny metal that bends like paper and is used for covering food
the end of something, especially something pointed

examples.text: tip of
He kissed the tip of her nose.
the southern tip of South America
lights on the wing tips of aeroplanes

definition.text: a small amount of additional money that you give to someone such as a waiter or a taxi driver

examples.text: Did you leave a tip ?
large/generous/big tip
I gave the guy a big tip .
a $5 tip

definition.text: a helpful piece of advice

examples.text: Perhaps she could give us a few tips .
tip on/for
This week's magazine has some tips on healthy eating.
handy tip(= useful tip )
handy tips for decorating a small flat
gardening tips

definition.text: a small sign of a problem that is much larger

examples.text: The reported cases of food poisoning are only the tip of the iceberg.

definition.lexUnit: on the tip of your tongue
definition.text:
a)if something is on the tip of your tongue, you really want to say it, but then you decide not to
b)if a word, name etc is on the tip of your tongue, you know it but cannot remember it

meaning.translation: آ) چیزی که واقعاً می خوای به زبون بیاری ولی بعدش منصرف میشی ب) نوک زبونمه (می دونمش ولی درست یادم نمیاد)

examples.text: It was on the tip of my tongue to say, ‘I’d rather have dinner with a snake.’
What is her name? It’s on the tip of my tongue. Joan. Joan Simpson. That’s it!

definition.text: an area where unwanted waste is taken and left

examples.text: a rubbish tip
I’ll take this lot to the tip.

definition.text: an extremely dirty or untidy place

meaning.translation: یک جای خیلی کثیف یا نامرتب

examples.text: The house was an absolute tip.

definition.text: special information about which horse will win a race
a secret warning or piece of information, especially to police about illegal activities

examples.text: Acting on a tip, the police were able to find and arrest Upton.

inflections: ( tipped, tipping )
title: tip_verb_1

definition.text: to move into a sloping position, so that one end or side is higher than the other, or to make something do this

examples.text: tip forward/back/to etc
His helmet had tipped forward and the boy pushed it back.
Eric fell asleep, his head gently tipping to one side.
tip something forward/back etc
‘So what?’ asked Brian, tipping his chair back on its rear legs.

inflections: ( tipped, tipping )
title: tip_verb_2

definition.text: to pour something from one place or container into another

meaning.translation: ریختن از یک جا یا ظرف به جا یا ظرف دیگر

examples.text: tip something onto/into something
Tip the onions and oil into a large ovenproof dish.
Ben tipped the contents of the drawer onto the table.
tip something out
Shall I tip the water out?

inflections: ( tipped, tipping )
title: tip_verb_3

definition.text: to give an additional amount of money to someone such as a waiter or taxi driver

examples.text: Did you tip the waiter?
tip somebody something
I tipped him $5.

inflections: ( tipped, tipping )
title: tip_verb_4

definition.text: if someone or something is tipped to do something, people think that they are most likely to succeed in doing it

examples.text: be tipped to do something
the man tipped to become the next president
be tipped for/as something
He’s tipped as a future world champion.
widely/strongly/hotly tipped
He had been widely tipped to get the new post of deputy director.

inflections: ( tipped, tipping )
title: tip_verb_5

definition.text: having a tip that is made of or covered with gold, steel etc

meaning.translation: دارای نوک طلایی ، فولادی ، پلاستیکی و غیره

examples.text: a silver-tipped walking stick

inflections: ( tipped, tipping )
title: tip_verb_6

definition.text: to give a slight advantage to someone or something

examples.text: Three factors helped to tip the balance in favour of the Labour leadership.

inflections: ( tipped, tipping )
title: tip_verb_7

definition.text: to weigh a particular amount, used especially of someone who will be taking part in a sports competition

examples.text: At today’s weigh-in he tipped the scales at just over 15 stone.

inflections: ( tipped, tipping )
title: tip_verb_8

definition.text: said when it is raining very heavily

examples.text: It was absolutely tipping it down.

inflections: ( tipped, tipping )
title: tip_verb_9

definition.text: to have one end covered in something

examples.text: arrows tipped with poison
red petals tipped with white

inflections: ( tipped, tipping )
title: tip_verb_10

definition.text:
a)to touch or raise your hat as a greeting to someone
b)to say or do something that shows you admire what someone has done

meaning.translation: لمس کردن یا برداشتن کلاه (به نشانه احترام)

inflections: ( tipped, tipping )
title: tip_verb_11

definition.text: to give someone secret information
one of the human speech sounds that you make by letting your breath flow out without closing any part of your mouth or throat
a letter of the alphabet used to represent a vowel . In English the vowels are a, e, i, o, u, and sometimes y .
a person who is responsible for a particular place and whose job is to make sure its rules are obeyed

examples.text: warden of
the warden of the college
forest/park etc warden

definition.text: the person in charge of a prison
someone who takes care of a building and the people in it, for example a place such as a home for old people

definition.lexUnit: ten pounds’ worth/$500 worth etc of something
definition.text: an amount of something worth ten pounds, $500 etc

examples.text: a chance to win £2,000 worth of computing equipment
The fire caused thousands of pounds’ worth of damage.

definition.lexUnit: ten minutes’ worth/a week’s worth etc of something
definition.text: something that takes ten minutes, a week etc to happen, do, or use

examples.text: We had only three days’ worth of food left.

definition.text: how good or useful something is or how important it is to people

examples.text: The new computer system has already proved its worth.

definition.text: how much money something is worth

examples.text: It is difficult to estimate the current worth of the company.

definition.text:
a)to have a value in money
b)to have money or possessions that have value

examples.text: The house must be worth quite a lot of money now.
One of the pictures is worth £50,000.
Do you know how much the ring is worth ?
This art collection is worth a fortune (= worth a very large amount of money ) .
be worth nothing/not be worth anything
It’s a very old machine so I shouldn’t think it’s worth anything.
I’ve heard that he’s worth over $2 million.
The man who founded the company must be worth a fortune .

definition.text:
a)used to say that something is interesting, useful, or helpful
b)used to say that someone should do something because they will gain something from it

examples.text: A lot of the small towns in the area are definitely worth visiting.
The film is well worth seeing.
worth a trip/visit etc
The local museum is worth a visit.
be worth doing something
It’s worth checking the details of the contract before you sign it.
It’s well worth getting there early if you want a good seat.
be worth the time/effort/work
It was a great evening, and definitely worth all the hard work.

definition.text: used to say that you gain something from an action

examples.text: It was a lot of hard work, but it was worth it .

definition.text: used to say that you do not gain anything from an action

examples.text: I thought about trying to talk to him about it, but decided it wasn’t worth it .

definition.lexUnit: be worth somebody’s while (to do/doing something)
definition.text: used to say that someone should spend time or money on something because they will gain something from it

examples.text: It might be worth your while to talk to the head of department.
Some people feel it’s not worth their while working if they can get money from the state.

definition.text: to offer something to someone so that they will do something for you

examples.text: He promised to make it worth our while.

definition.text: used humorously to ask someone how they will reward you if you do something for them

meaning.translation: چقدر برات می ارزه؟ (چی بهم پاداش میدی) (اگر اینکار رو برات انجام بدم)

definition.text: used when you are giving someone information, to say that you are not sure how useful it is

meaning.translation: نمی دونم چقدر به دردت می خوره

examples.text: Here’s the list of names, for what it’s worth.

definition.lexUnit: for all you are/he is etc worth
definition.text: with as much effort as possible

examples.text: He was pulling the rope for all he was worth.

definition.text: doing their job well or deserving respect

examples.text: Any player worth his salt would love to play for his country.

definition.lexUnit: worth your/its etc weight in gold
definition.text: very useful

meaning.translation: به اندازه وزنش ارزش طلا داره (خیلی باارزش و مفیده)

examples.text: In these mountains, an experienced guide is worth his weight in gold.

definition.text: the part of your body where your hand joins your arm

examples.text: on/around your wrist
She had a gold watch on her wrist.

definition.text: something that you compare another thing with, in order to judge how good or successful it is

examples.text: yardstick of
Profit is the most important yardstick of success for any business.
as a yardstick
These subjects are used as a yardstick against which to measure the children’s progress.

definition.text: a special stick used for measuring things, which is exactly one yard long
to love someone very much and feel very proud of them

examples.text: Betty adores her grandchildren.

definition.text: to like something very much

examples.text: I simply adore chocolate.

definition.text: to hit someone or something hard, in a way that causes pain or damage

meaning.translation: ییبی زدن (ضربه سنگین) به کسی یا چیزی

examples.text: Someone bashed him on the back of his head.
Police bashed down the door to get in.
bash something on/against something
He bashed his head on the back of the seat.
bash into
I accidentally bashed into a woman pushing a pram.

definition.text: to criticize someone or something very strongly

examples.text: He was always bashing the trade unions.

definition.text: a hard strong hit

meaning.translation: یک ضربه خیلی سنگین و سخت

examples.text: bash on
a bash on the head

definition.text: a party or an event to celebrate something

examples.text: a birthday bash

definition.text: to try to do something, especially when you are not sure that you will succeed

examples.text: Why not have a bash at windsurfing?

definition.text: to be trying to kiss someone and touch them, especially in a sexual way

examples.text: Before I could speak, he was all over me.

definition.text: used to say that you do not think something is as important as someone else thinks it is

examples.text: It’s just a game. If you lose, big deal.
What’s the big deal? It’s only a birthday, not the end of the world.
It’s no big deal . Everybody forgets things sometimes.

definition.text: an important or exciting event or situation

meaning.translation: یک اتفاق یا موقعیت مهم یا هیجان انگیز

examples.text: This audition is a big deal for Joey.

definition.lexUnit: make a big deal of/out of/about something
definition.text: to get too excited or upset about something, or make something seem more important than it is

meaning.translation: الکی بزرگ کردن چیزی (بیش از حد چیزی را مهم جلوه دادن)

examples.text: I know I’m probably making a big deal out of nothing, but I’m worried about you.

definition.text: if something breaks up, or if you break it up, it breaks into a lot of small pieces

examples.text: It seems that the plane just broke up in the air.
break something ↔ up
Use a fork to break up the soil.

definition.text: to separate something into several smaller parts

examples.text: There are plans to break the company up into several smaller independent companies.
You need a few trees and bushes to break up the lawn.

definition.text: to stop a fight

meaning.translation: جدا کردن آدم ها موقع دعوا

examples.text: Three policemen were needed to break up the fight.

definition.text: to make people leave a place where they have been meeting or protesting

examples.text: Government soldiers broke up the demonstration.
Police moved in to break up the meeting.

definition.text: if a marriage, group of people, or relationship breaks up, the people in it separate and do not live or work together anymore

examples.text: He lost his job and his marriage broke up .
The couple broke up last year.
Many bands break up because of personality clashes between the musicians.
with
Has Sam really broken up with Lucy?

definition.text: if a meeting or party breaks up, people start to leave

examples.text: The party didn’t break up until after midnight.
The meeting broke up without any agreement.

definition.text: when a school breaks up, it closes for a holiday

examples.text: School breaks up next week.
for
When do you break up for Easter?

definition.text: to make someone laugh by saying or doing something funny

examples.text: He breaks me up!
